title: Intel Logs Loss, Cuts Forecast as Sales Fall
text:
Chief Executive Pat Gelsinger said delays in the rollout of a new chip family for data centers and continued supply-chain troubles compounded the PC weakness.

The results were "below our expectations, below what we committed to our shareholders," he said, adding "we're quite disappointed by that."

The semiconductor titan had a net loss of $454 million.

Higher interest rates and inflation have hit consumers' pocketbooks around the world, and the return to in-person work has softened demand for PCs that people bought in droves over the past two years to facilitate remote work and distance schooling.

The division that houses Intel's PC chips reported a 25% fall in revenue to $7.7 billion, and sales at its data-center-chip division fell 16% to $4.6 billion.

PC customers are reducing inventory levels at a rate not seen in a decade, Mr. Gelsinger said in a call with analysts. PC makers typically reduce inventory levels of chips when they are expecting lower sales.

The chip maker said revenue in the current quarter should be $15 billion to $16 billion. Wall Street had been expecting sales of more than $18 billion. For the full year, Intel now expects sales of $65 billion to $68 billion, down from $76 billion.

Mr. Gelsinger said the sharp fall in consumer appetite would probably ease the global chip shortage that has persisted for two years.
